questions.explanation:
Solution:

Histone Nucleosomes = DNA + Histone proteins Histone proteins are rich in basic AA such as lysine and arginine, so, carry a positive charge. While DNA due to PO 4 2- groups has large negative charge. So, in nucleosomes, DNA and histones are tightly packed due to interaction between these opposite charges.

questions.text: The following histological image is seen in the patient who is complaining of growth failure and abdominal distension. Signs found were anemia, thrombocytopenia and bony pain. Which enzyme is deficient in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Beta-Glucocerebroside The image shows a crumpled tissue paper appearance of cell which is a characteristic feature of Gaucher’s disease. It is a sphingolipidoses and the most common lysosomal storage disease and occur due to deficiency of lysosomal enzyme β-glucocerebrosidase. The substrate glucosylceramide gets accumulated in macrophages causing eccentric nucleus. Other clinical features are: Bony pain, pathological fracture, hepatosplenomegaly but no mental retardation (as beta-glucosylceramide is not present in brain).

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Disease Enzyme Deficiency Niemann-Pick disease Sphingomyelinase Sandhoff's disease Hexosaminidase A and B Tay Sach’s Disease Hexosaminidase A Von Gierke’s Disease Glucose 6-phosphatase

questions.text: A paint factory worker working since 20 years complains of joint pain, insomnia, fatigue, constipation, headache. He is found to have anemia. Enzyme affected is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ferrochelatase The reference of paint factory worker indicates that it is a case of lead poisoning. Lead affects two enzymes of Heme synthesis pathway: PBG synthase Ferrochelatase (last enzyme of heme synthesis and adds Fe to its substrate) The defect in any of these enzymes will lead to decrease in haem synthesis resulting in anemia. So, the answer in this case is Ferrochelatase.

Solution:

Cyanide Inhibitor of ETC complexes Complexes Inhibitors Complex I Rotenone, Phenobarbitone, Amobarbital, and Piericidin A Complex II Malonate (3C), Carboxin (Fungicide) and TTFA (Trienoyl Tri Fluoro Acetone) Complex III Phenformin, Antimycin, Dimercaprol Complex IV CO, Cyanide (CN) , H 2 S and Sodium azide ADP to ATP conversion (Complex V) is inhibited by: Oligomycin ADP to ATP transfer is inhibited by: Atractyloside

Solution:

Myophosphorylase McArdle's disease is Type V glycogen storage disease that occurs due to deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase (Myophosphorylase) enzyme. In this disease, muscle glycogen cannot be used during exercise, so, on strenuous exercise there are muscles cramps. Also, normal or relatively low levels of lactate will be formed from muscle glycogen after exercise. Glycogen phosphorylase is a liver specific enzyme and its deficiency causes Her’s disease.

questions.text: A known patient of tuberculosis, on INH for the past 3 months complains of numbness, tingling and burning sensation in all the extremities. What could be vitamin deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vitamin B6 Isoniazid inhibits pyridoxal phosphokinase which is required for synthesis of biologically active form of pyridoxine (B6) i.e. pyridoxal phosphate. Thus, isoniazid inhibits the formation of the active form of B 6 . As Vit. B6 (PLP) is required for niacin (B 3 ) synthesis from tryptophan, hence isoniazid therapy also causes Niacin deficiency. In this question, best answer to mark is B 6 as INH directly inhibits B 6 formation.

questions.text: Cherry red spots on retina and mental retardation is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tay Sach’s disease By the method of exclusion: In Gaucher’s disease there is no mental retardation, so it can’t be the answer Hunter syndrome is an MPS with features such as coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly and skeletal abnormalities none of which is given here. So, option c is not the answer. Cherry red spot is found in most Sphingolipidoses except Gaucher’s disease, Krabbe’ disease and Fabry’s disease, so, option d can also be ruled out. So, only option left is Tay Sach’s disease and is the correct answer.

questions.text: FAD status in body is determined by?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glutathione reductase FAD is the active form of Vitamin B 2 and marker for the B 2 deficiency is RBC glutathione reductase activity as this enzyme require B 2 as coenzyme. So, in case of FAD deficiency, glutathione reductase activity will be lowered without affecting the quantity of enzyme. RBC transketolase activity is used as marker to know the deficiency of Vitamin B 1 (Thiamine)

questions.correct_answer: B. Aerobic glycolysis with lactate formation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aerobic glycolysis with lactate formation Warburg effect This effect occurs in cancerous cells. This is a paradox from normal in the sense that Cancer cells convert pyruvate to lactate even in the presence of O 2 . This is known as aerobic glycolysis (option b is true). Energy derived from conversion of pyruvate to lactate is just 2 ATPs (option c is false) , hence rapidly growing cancer cells take up large amount of glucose (option d is false) compared to normal cells. Due to large amount of glucose used, patients have Cachexia (weight loss).

questions.text: A Mediterranean person didn’t receive primaquine. Which pathway is affected by G-6-PD enzyme deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HMP pathway G6PD is the first and rate limiting enzyme of HMP pathway which is the major source of NADPH that is required for reduced glutathione generation and help reduce oxidative stress by neutralizing free radicals. Primaquine is an antimalarial drug and causes oxidative stress. In patients with Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase ( G6PD) deficiency, primaquine can cause hemolysis so it is avoided.

questions.text: True about telomeres and telomerase is:

options.label: B
options.text: Gradually decreasing length of telomeres with ageing

options.label: D
options.text: Telomerase is found in somatic cells

questions.correct_answer: B. Gradually decreasing length of telomeres with ageing
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gradually decreasing length of telomeres with ageing Telomeres are end of chromosomes and do not contain any coding sequences (option c is false) instead it has TTAGGG sequence repeated ‘n’ no. of times. Telomerase is enzyme present only in the germ/stem cells and is responsible for maintaining the length of telomeres due to its RNA dependent DNA polymerase activity. In Somatic cells, absence of telomerase enzyme (option d is false) results in telomere shortening as the cells ages (option b is true and option a is false).

questions.text: When a codon is changed to stop codon, then it is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Non-sense mutation Non-sense mutation: Amino acid codon is replaced by a stop codon causing premature termination of translation and truncated protein. Mis-sense mutation: Codon for one amino acid is replaced by another amino acid codon causing change in protein properties. Silent mutation: Codon is changed but amino acid is not changed due to codon degeneracy, so no effect on resulting protein .

questions.text: Condition shown below is due to which vitamin deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vitamin A This is Bitot’s spot shown in the picture due to vitamin A deficiency. There is build-up of keratin located superficially in conjunctiva. This can be oval, triangular or irregular in shape. This is also associated with conjunctival xerosis.

questions.text: Rice water diarrhoea, intoxication is due to which ganglioside?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

GM-1 ganglioside receptor Rice water diarrhoea occurs due to cholera and mechanism of action of cholera toxin include activation of GM-1 ganglioside receptor.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of botulinum toxin is:

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibits release of acetylcholine from lower motor neurons

questions.correct_answer: C. Inhibits release of acetylcholine from lower motor neurons
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inhibits release of acetylcholine from lower motor neurons Mechanism of action of Botulinum toxin or tetanus toxin involves inhibition of release of acetylcholine from lower motor neurons.

questions.text: Fatty acid transport through mitochondrial membrane is via?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Carnitine Fatty acid transport into mitochondria from cytoplasm involve the carnitine shuttle system using enzymes Carnitine Palmitoyl Transferase-I (CPT-I) and CPT-II. CPT-I is RLE of fatty acid transport or beta-oxidation of fatty acid.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Acyl Carrier protein (ACP) is required for fatty acid synthesis as a part of enzyme fatty acid synthase complex. LCAT (Lecithin Cholesterol Acyl Transferase) is an enzyme present in HDL and helps in conversion of HDL cholesterol to HDL cholesterol ester by transfer of a fatty acyl group from Lecithin to cholesterol.

questions.text: A woman on anti-depressants presents with bleeding. She gives a history of bulky stools which sticks to the pan. Which of the following vitamin deficiency can cause bleeding in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vitamin K The symptoms of patient indicate steatorrhea or fat malabsorption. In this condition, fat-soluble vitamins will also be poorly absorbed and can become deficient. All the options given are of fat-soluble vitamins. Now, question also ask which vitamin deficiency can cause bleeding, so the answer will be vitamin K as it is required for prevention of bleeding by addition of carboxy groups to the clotting factors 2,7 9, and 10.

questions.text: Identify the acid base disorder in a patient with the following values: pH- 7.2 and pCO2 – 80 mm Hg
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Respiratory acidosis As pH = 7.2 of the patient’s blood is lower than normal blood pH= 7.35-7.45, so, it’s a case of acidosis. As the acidosis is due to pCO 2 = 80 mm of Hg that is higher than normal pCO 2 = 35-45 mm of Hg, so, it’s a case of respiratory acidosis rather than metabolic acidosis which occurs due to decreased HCO 3 -

questions.text: Which of the following has autosomal recessive pattern of inheritence?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cystic fibrosis AD (Autosomal Dominant) Familial hypercholesterolemia Huntington's disease Lactose Intolerance Marfan Syndrome Myotonic Dystrophy AD Polycystic Kidney Disease Porphyria Variegate AR (Autosomal Recessive) Ataxia Telangiectasia Cystic fibrosis Familial Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy Sickle Cell disease Thalassemia Maple Syrup Urine disease Homocystinuria Alkaptonuria Hemochromatosis Albinism Phenylketonuria Wilson's disease Hemochromatosis AR Polycystic Kidney disease Orotic Aciduria Glycogen Storage Diseases Mucopolysaccharidosis (except Hunter’s) All sphingolipidosis except Fabry’s disease
